comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Wonderful street photography and captures the essence of the period beautifully!  You could spend hours poring over this and admiring the details.  The noise level on the street during rush hour must have been considerable with the steel tyres on the wheels and those cobbles to rattle over. "I'd like a room at the back please sir???"  Is that a soldier at the rere of the tram? He looks a lot more military than transport company in that uniform, quite smart really.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: The Tramways Act 1870. In the days of horse trams, promoters were required to maintain "so much of the road as extends eighteen inches beyond the rails of and on each side of any such tramway". This continued into the electric tram era. www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/Vict/33-34/78/section/28?vie...

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Indeed. It's not the only public clock to "vanish" from Bridge Street however. Take the case of the (granted much much newer and less ornate) one which AIB "moved" when they closed their Bridge Street branch. Maybe the other lovely clock found a new home also.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] Well, it looks as if the Cork Electric Tramways and Lighting Company were obeying the Tramways Act - plenty of space either side of rails...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: Tram conductors often wore a uniform with a double row of bright buttons. Here are some from Newcastle upon Tyne www.flickr.com/photos/newcastlelibraries/4080472609/ Some Gateshead Tramways leather money pouches were still being used on the buses in the 1980s.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] Thanks for the pic (great photostream), and I'm with you on the conductor vote. Though [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] and [http://www.flickr.com/photos/int0lerant] are convinced it's a soldier...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: I wouldn't go so far as to say I'm convinced that he's a soldier but that he is very military in appearance.  Very smartly turned out, single row of polished buttons, cap peak cut and pulled so that it comes down quite straight and brightly polished.  He does seem to have the leather pouch for the money and he also has his left hand on the crane thing for moving the overhead electrical connector.  Those two should indicate that he is the conductor.  I also remember one or two of the "lockhards" unofficial parking attendants on the streets of Dublin for many years whose caps would have put many a soldier to shame!  The man in the front of the photograph in Blackpoolbeach's link looks like he was a former soldier also?

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: Women were recruited as tram conductors in the First World War, then they were sacked when the men came back from the war. The Newcastle conductors were most likely ex-servicemen. I bet the bloke front row right had been a Regimental Sergeant Major, judging by the sharp creases in his trousers. Here is a woman tram conductor in Bristol www.flickr.com/photos/brizzlebornandbred/2048838443/

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] [RE] "Very surprised you don't know about the one in this photo". I really shouldn't be swayed by this obvious prod. But I did a quick scan of resources. The photo puts that clock at #5 Bridge Street c.1900/1901. At that time #5 was (according to the Almanacs and 1901 Census) occupied by a family of jewellers and watchmakers named Barriscale. Hence no big surprise that they had a handsome timepiece adorning their shop-front. The Barriscale's were a long established family of jewellers and watchmakers in Cork:
* Slater's 1846 directory puts a Samuel Barriscale in a jeweller/watchmakers shop on Paul Street. * Guy's 1884 directory puts a William Barriscale (likely a descendant of the above) close-by operating as a jeweller/watchmaker on North Main Street (Crawford Art College records of the 1880s suggest he may have been a graduate - perhaps as a silversmith) * Guy's 1891 directory shows 5 Bridge street as vacant * However, by 1901 the Census puts William Barriscale (and HIS son Richard) at 5 Bridge Street * Guy's 1907 directory shows that William Barriscale was still at 5 Bridge Street * The same directory suggests that an RJ Barriscale (very likely Richard) had opened a jewellers/watchmakers in 12a Winthrop Street (incidentally a lovely building in itself. Now occupied by Minihan's Chemist) * Intervening directories show that the Barriscale shop operated on Bridge Street until at least 1921 (Richard had left the Winthrop Street shop by this time. Perhaps he moved away or back to Bridge Street to support his father - who would have been in his 70s by then) * Guy's 1945 directory however lists no Barriscale's operating as jewellers in Cork (Richard possibly having moved or passed away himself. And the elder William certainly having passed away by then)
I know this doesn't answer the "where's the clock?" challenge, but perhaps it might prompt any remaining Barriscale's in Cork (of which there are a few) to shed some light. (Did Richard move and take it with him to a new premises? Did it stay at 5 Bridge Street for a time?) Personally I dunno.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/20727502@N00] Do apologise for putting undue pressure on you!  Though take exception to "obvious prod" - thought I was being very subtle...  ;)

What a wealth of info, though, and I thank you for it. Have checked really hi-res image and it does say Barriscale on no. 5 (and I think) on the clock face. William Barriscale is listed at no. 5 under Opticians too in Guy's Directory, 1907
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [SNAP - Consecutive post with above] Actually. Just looking at the photo again now. It's not clear on even the highest resolution, but it seems to say "BARRISCALE" on the face of the clock. If so, it would surely have been the family's own clock. And therefore likely would have moved or been sold when the Barriscale's left the premises. (Per above this was likely in the mid to late 1920s or 1930s.)

I tinted the buildings, sharpened the trees in the background, cleaned the street a bit, added a dreamy ambiance of nostalgia (the girl is daydreaming of a previous time in Ireland) and imposed my will on nature (night sky in the daytime). The latter comes with the license of a whimsical digital artist and his indifference to reason.

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content:
There's so much going on in this photo I keep coming back to it :)

I was talking to family about the clock the other day, and my dad (who - like myself - walked Bridge St every day to school) recons it was still there in his time. Late 50s and maybe into the 60s. Anecdotal evidence only I know, but does suggest that the clock stayed after the Barriscale shop closed or moved. Revisited the old route at the weekend also - and the mounting holes/etc are still visible today. 

Also my eagle-eyed family noted two motor cars on Patrick's Hill in the background. Given that there were likely only a few dozen cars in the whole country at the time, (and most of them in Dublin) it's interesting that we find two in this shot. And the two brave drivers are testing their machines on one of the steepest urban hills in the country! Guy's Almanac didn't start recording the city's motor car owners until the later part of the decade, but would love to know more about the guy in that smashing driving suit :)

comment._content: Fantastic. One of my favorites for sure. Thanks for all these beautiful old photo's of Cork your've had some brilliant ones :)

comment._content: 1911 census results for Cork Samuel Daniel HAPPER, chauffeur to William George JAMESON, Distiller Albert William SRARROTT (?), chauffeur to Isabel Travers HALL Patrick NEWTON, chauffeur to Hugh Conrad GREER, District Inspt. RIC Cornelius O'BRIEN, chauffeur to Arthur Wellesley SANDFORD, M.D.,M.Ch.,Ophthalmic Surgeon There are 125 chauffeurs for all of Ireland in the 1911 census results, but none in 1901. www.census.nationalarchives.ie/search/results.jsp?census_...

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Many drivers in those days wore "Dust Coats and covers" as they were very exposed to the elements and the dust and dirt that was thrown up by their travels and other traffic. The driver in this instance looks as though it is a suit he is wearing. Chalkie_CC has some shots of a De Dion Bouton and they compare very favourably with the car in this shot. www.flickr.com/photos/chalkie_circle2000/2468589846/

comment.author: 40911801@N00
comment._content: Behind the clock at 4 Bridge Street was the boot shop of my great great grandfather William McNay (1835-1916)

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/achesonblog] That is amazing! William McNay is clearly visible and I had already tagged with his name. Did the shop stay in the family at all after 1916?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 40911801@N00
comment._content: I believe the shop and home remained in the family until the 1940s. William's son, also named William (1861-1945), continued in the boot business. William McNay (1861-1945) seated left: www.flickr.com/photos/achesonblog/5034352581/in/set-72157...

comment.author: 40911801@N00
comment._content: In the first floor window above Twomey's public house on the corner of Coburg Street are the offices of the N.S. & F.U. The National Seamens' and Firemens' Union was a British based union not well thought of by Connolly and others in Irish Labour.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/achesonblog] How lovely that you have that photo! William looks like a very dapper gentleman...

comment.author: 75586270@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/20727502@N00]  Amazing photograph of the Barriscale shop. My Great grandfather was William Barriscale who owned the shop and I believe it stayed open until the early 1940's. I have tried to find where the clock went as far as I can ascertain it was donated to the African missions and is lost. Richard emigrated to Canada and continued to work their as an optician.  Would be very interested to see any other photographs you have in your collection.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/75586270@N02] How tremendous! Thanks a million for getting in touch. As you can see from the comments above, everyone was fascinated by the Mystery of the Disappearing Clock. guliolopez's father thought it was still there in the 50s/even into the 60s. What do you know about timing (if you'll pardon the pun)? Do you think the clock stayed for some years after the shop itself closed? If I come across another photo of your family's shop, I will certainly post them here...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/75586270@N02] Smashing! I knew that one of the remaining Cork Barriscale's would shed some light :) Glad to hear that Richard kept the business going after he left Cork. Pity to hear about the uncertain fate of the clock though.

comment.author: 77653978@N03
comment._content: Fantastic photo and some great comments demonstrating some amazing knowledge of turn of the century Cork. My family owned Landons Printing Works and Book Factory which was at number 16 from at least 1845 up until some time in the 60s I think. Some of you might even remember it. Thanks so much for a truly remarkable photo.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
